qas.question: What occurs when someone uses a trademark that is identical or confusingly similar to a trademark owned by someone else?
What does registering a trademark provide?
Where is a trademark protected without registration?
How is trademark infringement addressed in most jurisdictions?
How is trademark infringement addressed in a few jurisdictions?
What occurs when someone uses an identical trademark but not when the use a similar trademark
What this trademark protection require in most jurisdictions?
A trademark without what receives the same legal advantages as a registered trademark?
What is addressed by criminal law in all jurisdictions?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Trademark infringement<b5_0/><a0_0/> occurs when one party uses a trademark that is identical or confusingly similar to a trademark owned by another party, in relation to products or services which are identical or similar to the products or services of the other party. <a2_0>In many countries<a2_0/>, a trademark receives protection without <b6_0><b7_0>registration<b7_0/><b6_0/>, but registering a trademark provides <a1_0>legal advantages for enforcement<a1_0/>. <b8_0>Infringement<b8_0/> can be addressed by <a3_0>civil litigation<a3_0/> and, in several jurisdictions, under <a4_0>criminal law<a4_0/>.
